subject: Come to the Westerlands
event:
An old/ new sample just went up on my website, for those who cannot get enough of Fake History.

I've uploaded the history of the Westerlands, from THE WORLD OF ICE AND FIRE.  This is the version I read last year at Loncon, slightly longer than the text that appears in the actual book, which was edited and trimmed a bit.  For those who want every last little nugget...

You will find it under Samples/ World of Ice & Fire, where it replaces the Aegon's Conquest sample that had been up there for a year.

And if that whets your appetite for more, the worldbook is still available from your favorite local bookstore or online retailer.

props.taglist: world of ice and fire, website

comments.article:
slightly longer than the text that appears in the actual book,

There is never enough fake history! Thank you, George!
comments.subject: Awesome.

comments.article: I bought the book and was very pleased with it. Some of the best worldbuilding I have read. I have a question though - will we learn more about the mysterious black stones on Iron Islands, Hightower and Yeen in the novels? Will we learn more about the Deep Ones? or will it remain a mystery, like asshai?

I want to hear more tales of Southros, or any of what was mentioned above.

Perhaps this would be a good starting place for an anthology...
Must... read... every last word... of anything related to ASOIAF...
comments.subject: Obsessed

comments.article:
Imagine you're watching the Super Bowl. Jets vs. Dallas! You've anticipated this game for months, listened to all the press conferences, got excited and you have great seats to the game. Somewhere around halftime the game gets delayed because of weather...

But something funny happens during the delay - the scoreboard keeps updating with the future results of the game. Every touchdown, every penalty.

By the time the delays are over and the 3rd quarter is under way, the scoreboard already has the final score of the game. Dallas wins 28 - 21. Now you can sit there and see how it gets to that score, but isn't your experience tainted? If you know all the major twists and turns in the game, how can you really enjoy it? Change months of anticipation in this scenario to 20 years for some and I think the disappointment is clear.

Realize I'm derailing but there's never a good place to vent your frustrations about the shows passing the book and apparently no one working together to prevent it.

This whole scenario will be remembered in a derogatory way. Similar to how people fear that a show will have a "LOST ending", authors will now joke about trying to avoid a "GAME OF THRONES ending" where the readers get screwed and the author's story gets told essentially through fan fiction (which you ironically don't allow!).
comments.subject: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article: I don't think you quite grasp what 'fan fiction' is or why I object to it.  GAME OF THRONES is a licensed adaptation.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article: Not sure if you remember this, but when they did the Deeper Than Swords exhibit at Texas A & M, they had several prints from a local artist featuring quotes from the books, plus one print with Neil Gaiman's famous "George R R Martin is not your bitch." quote.  Anyway, long story short, I bought a copy of that print from the artist and had Neil Gaiman sign it at one of his The Ocean at the End of the Lane signings.  If you'd like, I can scan it in and send it to you, and you can put it up on your homepage for people like this.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article:
I just read on a formerly well respected fan site that their would be an Indian version of game of the to thrones with several actors cast. I trust this fits in the "do not believe everything you read" category...

However I heard an interview with Finn jones where he said he had read a fanfic on him and get him Anthony rubbing pizza on each other. The stuff people come up with.... Apparently this is real though :S

Anyway thanks for a the excerpt!
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article:
Speaking of fan fiction, were you aware of this? http://winteriscoming.net/2015/03/26/india-is-making-game-of-thrones-heres-what-we-know/
I doubt you have OK'd this.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article: Look, when it comes to the book and the show, this is how I feel about it. One is apple pie while the other is pumpkin. They're similar experiences but the devil is in the details. In the end, I'm not going to complain if either is set on the table because IT'S STILL PIE.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article:
Mr Martin, I know you already said you wouldn't let someone else finish your books, but have you considered hiring a ghost writer to help you with the slow (boring?) parts of writing?

You could write what happens in a straightforward style and have them embellishing the text. For instance, you'd write "Tyrion kills a dragon with his axe" and he/she would translate that into "It's a cold winter night. The fiery beast lusts for blood. Tyrion, however - the braveest imp ever - lusts for life. He raises his arms, his weapon, his fury! He won't meet r'hllor without fighting! ... etc etc etc...

Not trying to tell you how to run your business here, just wondering if this "solution" ever occurred to you, as it seems you did something similar for the HBO show (gave them some sort of outline for the whole series).
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article: No, no way.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?
Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article:
I'd rather wait 20 years for GRRM's real novel than read 1500 pages of ghostwritten bilge.

Got any other atrocities on your mind? May as well get them out now while our guts are clenched for the sucker punch.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article:
I enjoy the TV series for what it is, but I sort of agree with the above poster in that after the first season the series essentially became fan fiction. The personalities and motivations of the characters are dramatically altered resulting in a loss of the original intent and spirit much of the time. Sometimes the new fiction works and sometimes it seems like D&D have meager powers of reading comprehension. For example, consider the amateur move to leave out Jamie telling Tyrion the truth about Tysha despite having time for that weird discourse on the imbecile bug crusher. That was arrogant fan fiction by guys who read the books ONCE and thought they could do better.

"Licensed adaptation" is just an euphemism for "the fan fiction writers gave me dump trucks of money". Nothing wrong with that so long as we call it what it is.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article: I admit I feel slightly awkward about the situation as well. However I don't know why you people think you have the right to be so rude to George's face, as if he wasn't aware of the situation. The reason you can't find a good place to vent on his forum is because THIS IS NOT THE PLACE TO DO IT. If you truly feel that you are getting "screwed" then by all means leave the fandom, from what I've seen it is no great loss.
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article:
I do feel a little rude, "you're not wrong" to steal an ASOIAF expression. I just feel screwed and I don't think that my feeling is unjustified. Had I known that the show would be pre-empting the books I would have never started the books, or maybe just started them after the show was over. When most of us started the series, 5, 10, 15 years ago, we had no reason to expect this.

It's like watching a movie and then getting a text message midway through spoiling the rest of the movie. Would you have gone to that movie if you knew that you would be getting those texts? I know I'm really hitting the metaphors hard here and I apologize for my negativity but I AM PISSED!!

The biggest thing that bugs me is that this can be avoided but no one's really saying why it's not being avoided. We know HBO wants more like 10 seasons, we know George can certainly use more time, so are D&D just saying "Meh, sorry. We're gonna do what we want. Shouldn't have told us the ending - sucker!"? Is there no collaboration, no urgency to resolve this without screwing book readers? Maybe the end result will be the same but I just wish there was a more frank and open discussion on why this can't be avoided other than "it is what it is".
comments.subject: Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?
Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?
Re: LOST ending: Jets in the Superbowl?

comments.article: Does any other region have a longer version? It was kind of disappointing to see the North with only 9 pages or so.

George, my favorite thing about your fake history is that it acts like real history. We should be skeptical of some events, and we can apply historical criticism to the sources we do have to figure out the best explanation of what really happened.
comments.subject: Fake History

comments.article:
This sample says Maekar was killed in Starpike, while the Targaryen section of the book says he was killed in the Dornish Marches.
Was that an oversight or is that where Starpike is located? Does this mean part of the Dornish Marches proper are still located within the Reach?

George,

Thanks for uploading this -- it scratches the itch for more pseudo history! Do you imagine that this extended version will end up in published format in FIRE AND BLOOD someday down the road? I also have to imagine with all the cuts to THE WORLD OF ICE AND FIRE, that you have a lot of good material and running headstart for tackling FIRE AND BLOOD after the main series concludes.

Anyways, thanks again!
comments.subject: Extended Editions of Chapters

comments.article: Always happy to read your little fake histories. I absolutely adore TPaTQ
comments.subject: Thanks a ton Mr. Martin

comments.article: Speaking of fake histories, in a throw back Thursday kind of moment I stumbled back on your write up of how Ser Jaime Lannister was able to defeat Rand al'Thor in a Trial of Seven. That was definitely some epic writing that fans of the fantasy world in general should read.
comments.subject: Suvudu Cage Matches

comments.article: Boy the maester who laid down this history really loves slobbering on Lannister nob! Lol! No but seriously I'm sure their lion shaped rock is beautiful as they come. I was wondering if we could expect a lengthened history of The North, maybe a little more detail on the battles fought and the betrayals suffered during the wars with the First Kings of Dustin or the Red Kings of Bolton? Very excited for TWOW and anytime we get new material it's a good day! Thanks much George!
comments.subject: Seven Blessings to ya!

comments.article: I'm dyin' to read more about the Targaryen history, and it reads like it was the most fun to write as well. Summerhall may be reserved for a D&E novella, but you could delete that part... : )
comments.subject: Any chance you'll post the Targaryen History (long form)?

comments.article:
The Targaryen history will eventually form the spine of the GRRMarillion... years from now.

It will be MUCH longer than the Westerlands history here.
comments.subject: Re: Any chance you'll post the Targaryen History (long form)?
